definition: in confusion or disorder/in a confused state of mind/disorder/upheaval/riot/illicit sexual relations/to throw into disorder/to mix up/indiscriminate/random/arbitrary

sentences.english: A morning routine can also help you get out the door faster with little fuss.
sentences.chinese: 早晨的常规活动也可以帮你免去忙乱之忧快些出门。

sentences.english: I profited by his confusion to make my escape .
sentences.chinese: 我趁他忙乱的时候逃走了。

sentences.english: this week will be rather hectic on the domestic scene.
sentences.chinese: 本周家中的事情将非常忙乱。

sentences.english: I hate all this fussy packing.
sentences.chinese: 我不喜欢忙乱地整理行装。

sentences.english: If there's a bustle in your hedgerow , don't be alarmed now.
sentences.chinese: 如果你的心头一阵忙乱，现在不要惊慌。

sentences.english: She fussed around all the time.
Get up fifteen minutes earlier in the morning. The inevitable morning mishaps will be less stressful.
sentences.chinese: 每天早晨提前15分钟起床，忙乱的早上将变得从容。

sentences.english: They don't like a fuss, but set themselves and others high standards.
sentences.chinese: 他们不喜欢忙乱，对自己和对他人都定有较高标准。

sentences.english: There is always a certain flurry in a country-house on Sunday morning.
sentences.chinese: 在乡村居室里，星期天上午照例有一翻忙乱。

sentences.english: They will keep one another sane for the first chaotic year.
sentences.chinese: 她们将忙乱的年使彼此明智。

sentences.english: Hurry is the death of prayer.

definition: to act with confusion/to be in a flurry/to be flustered
noisy and in disarray/in an uproar
see 驚慌失措|惊慌失措[jing1 huang1 shi1 cuo4]
to lose one's head out of fear (idiom)
lit. badly burned about the head (from trying to put out a fire) (idiom)/fig. hard-pressed/under pressure (from a heavy workload, creditors etc)
